subject: Re: Including test cases with production code
msgSnippet: I also think this would be a very nice thing. ... If I was using a product and changed my system in some way (operating system patch/upgrade, JMS provider or
messageBody:
I also think this would be a very nice thing.

> Having a special hook in the app to enable running unit tests on
> production hardware & software setup might prove valuable when
> you suspect a problem with a JVM for example.

If I was using a product and changed my system in some way (operating
system patch/upgrade, JMS provider or JCE provide switch, new
JDK ...), it would be reasuring to be able to run a POST or some
basic tests to ensure that the product still worked.

I could see myself running unit tests on a nightly or weekly basis,
even, adding it to my administration task list: Perform backups,
defrag disks, run virus check, ... run unit tests.


--- In junit@y..., "Mathieu Gervais" <egoine_@h...> wrote:
> I agree with Michael Silverstein (below).
> "Customer" is so vague!
> In my original post, I talked about going into "production" because
that's
> the type of work I do. I don't do code for "consumers" style end-
users.
> More like a system that is put into production at some point, not
an app
> installed on a desktop. Having a special hook in the app to enable
running
> unit tests on production hardware & software setup might prove
valuable when
> you suspect a problem with a JVM for example.
>
> I totally agree with what Michael expressed below. In my case, I
currently
> work for an IT departement that wants to maintain the code on it's
own after
> the project (so "source code is provided"). They are buying code,
and we
> give them tests as an added bonus. As for bandwith & storage, I
think it is
> a moot point. How much for a 20 Gig theses days? If the code is not
an
> applet, I don't see why it would generate bandwith loss more than me
> downloading mp3s ;)
>
> mathieu
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Michael Silverstein
>
> Definitely if source code is provided, including test cases make
sense. I
> think we all agree now that within the context of end-user
application
> deployment, it doesn't make sense to include test cases, except for
special
> diagnostic circumstances. If a product deliverable includes source
code, or
> is a framework that provides a set of Java APIs, then a set of test
cases is
> invaluable for documenting and validating product usage.
